Homage to Bodhisattva Unimpeded Mind I take refuge in these and other immeasurable and boundless great bodhisattva mahÄsattvas in the worlds of the ten directions.
I respectfully bow to the Å›rÄvakas, pratyekabuddhas, and all the sages.

Homage to Ä€jÃ±Ätakauá¹‡á¸inya, Homage to MahÄkÄÅ›yapa, Homage to UruvilvÄ-KÄÅ›yapa, Homage to GayÄ-KÄÅ›yapa, Homage to NadÄ«-KÄÅ›yapa, Homage to ÅšÄriputra, Homage to MahÄmaudgalyÄyana, Homage to MahÄkÄtyÄyana, Homage to Aniruddha, Homage to MahÄkaphina - I take refuge in these well-known great arhats and others.
Having paid homage to the Three Jewels, I will next repent.
Disciples!
Having repented the afflictive hindrances and having repented the karmic hindrances, I will now in order confess and repent the remaining karmic hindrances.
The sÅ«tras say:

When the retribution of karma arrives, it is not in empty space, nor in the ocean, nor entering the mountains and rocks, nor in any other place that one can escape and not receive retribution. Only the power of repentance can cause it to be extinguished.
How do we know this?

When Åšakra DevÄnÄm-Indra's five signs of decline appeared, he was deeply afraid and sincerely took refuge in the Three Jewels. The signs of death immediately disappeared and he extended his heavenly lifespan.
There are many such examples clearly stated in the scriptures and teachings. Therefore, we know that repentance can truly eliminate misfortune.

However, ordinary people, if not guided by good friends, will commit all kinds of evil. As a result, when their great life is about to end and they reach the brink of death, the evil signs of hell all appear before them.
At that time, remorse and fear arise together. If they do not cultivate goodness in advance, they will regret it only when they reach the brink of death. What use is regret at that point?
Misfortunes from different places are prepared in advance and await them. They will go alone to a distant place and enter a large cauldron. Their body and mind are crushed and their spirit suffers.
At that time, how can they hope to make a single prostration or repentance?

Do not be self-indulgent, lazy, negligent, or unrestrained, thinking that the suffering of death will not come to you, regardless of whether you are young or old, poor or rich, noble or humble. It will suddenly arrive and no one will know.
Life is impermanent, like morning dew. Although the outgoing breath may still be present, the incoming breath is difficult to guarantee. Why not repent of this?
As for the five messengers who come, the ghost of impermanence suddenly arrives, and even those in their prime cannot escape.
At that time, the spacious and lofty halls have nothing to do with human affairs.
The high carriages and large horses cannot follow by themselves. The wife, children, and relatives are no longer my own. The seven precious treasures and ornaments are enjoyed by others.

Based on this, it can be said that all the fruits and retributions in the world are like illusions. Although the upper heavens are blissful, they will eventually return to destruction. When the lifespan is exhausted, the soul falls into the three evil paths.
Therefore, the Buddha said to Subhadra:

'Your teacher Udraka Ramaputra was of sharp faculties, wise, and able to subdue afflictions, yet he reached the state of neither perception nor non-perception and died, only to be reborn as a flying fox in the animal realm, let alone the rest.'

Therefore, know that those who have not yet realized the fruits of sainthood will all continue to transmigrate and experience evil destinies. If one is not careful, one will suddenly encounter this matter and will not be able to repent.

Or, like now when one is punished and goes to the public office, this is already a small suffering. The mind is agitated and frightened, and relatives are fearful, seeking help in a hundred ways. The various sufferings of hell compared to this are a million times more, not even comparable. We have all experienced sins like Mount Sumeru throughout kalpas.
How can we hear this and remain calm, fearless, unalarmed, and unafraid?
Allowing this spirit to again experience this suffering is truly painful.
Therefore, disciples!
Use this single sincerity and utmost sincerity to take refuge in the Buddha.

Homage to the Buddha of Taming in the East, Homage to the Buddha of Diamond Treasury in the South, Homage to the Buddha of Lamp of the Dharma Realm in the West, Homage to the Buddha of Boundless Eyes in the North, Homage to the Buddha of Virtuous Freedom in the Southeast, Homage to the Buddha of Destroying All Fears in the Southwest, Homage to the Buddha of Heroic Subjugation in the Northwest, Homage to the Buddha of Powerful Light in the Northeast, Homage to the Buddha of Joyful Path in the Nadir, Homage to the Buddha of Incense Superior King in the Zenith. I take refuge in the Three Jewels in the ten directions and throughout the realm of space.
Disciples!

From beginningless time until today, all karmic hindrances have been extinguished. The heaviest of these is only the AvÄ«ci Hell, as explained in the sÅ«tras. Now I will briefly describe its characteristics.

This hell is surrounded by seven layers of iron walls, and there are seven layers of iron nets covering above. Below there are seven layers of sword forests and immeasurable fierce fires, extending 84,000 yojanas in length and breadth.

The bodies of the offenders fill the entire space, and due to their karmic actions they do not obstruct each other. The fire above penetrates below and the fire below penetrates above, passing through the east, west, south, and north. Like fish in a roasting pan with all the fat gone, the suffering in this hell is also like this.
At the four gates of the city there are four large bronze dogs, their bodies extending 40 yojanas in length and breadth, with sharp teeth and claws, and eyes like lightning.
There are also immeasurable iron-beaked birds, soaring and flying, pecking at the flesh of the offenders. The ox-headed wardens have bodies like rÄká¹£asas, with nine tails like iron forks.

There are also eight heads, each head has eighteen horns, and there are sixty-four eyes, each eye spurts out molten iron balls, burning the flesh of the sinners. When it roars with anger, the sound is like thunder.

There are also countless natural swords and wheels falling from the sky, entering from the crown of the sinners' heads and exiting from their feet. The pain penetrates to the marrow and the suffering pierces the liver and heart.
Thus, for countless years, they experience various sufferings, unable to find life or death.
Such retributions, I now all bow my head in shame and reveal them, sincerely repenting.

The remaining hells, such as the sword mountain and tree of swords hell, where bodies and heads fall off, I repent of the retribution for that offense.ğŸ”½The boiling cauldron and furnace charcoal hell, I repent of the retribution for being burned and cooked there.ğŸ”½The iron bed and copper pillar hell, I repent of the retribution for being scorched there.
The sword wheel and fire cart hell, I repent of the retribution for being crushed there.
The hell of having one's tongue plowed, with the painful retribution of sins, we repent.

The hell of swallowing iron pellets and pouring molten copper into the mouth, with the painful retribution of the five viscera rotting, we repent.ğŸ”½The hell of iron pestles and iron grinders, with the painful retribution of bones and flesh being ground to dust, we repent.

The hell of black ropes and iron nets, with the painful retribution of limbs being separated, we repent.ğŸ”½The hell of the ash river and boiling excrement, with the painful retribution of distress, we repent.
The hell of salty water and cold ice, with the painful retribution of the skin cracking and being naked and frozen, we repent.
The hell of tigers, wolves, hawks, and dogs, with the painful retribution of further mutual predation, we repent.
The hell of weapons, divided claws, with the painful retribution of further mutual stabbing and slashing, we repent.
The hell of fire pits, with the painful retribution of being roasted, we repent.ğŸ”½The hell of two rocks grinding together, with the painful retribution of the body being crushed, we repent.
The hell of gathering and black ears, with the painful retribution of being dissected, we repent.
The dark and gloomy meat mountain hell, the retribution of being cut and chopped, we repent.ğŸ”½The saw-cutting and nail-piercing hell, the retribution of being cut and pierced, we repent.
The iron hook and hanging upside down hell, the retribution of being slaughtered, we repent.
The burning and screaming hell, the retribution of being tormented, we repent.
Between the great iron mountains, the long night is dark and gloomy, not recognizing the three luminaries, we repent.
The Apapa hell, the Asasa hell, the Ata-ata hell, the A-la-la hell, these eight cold and eight hot hells, in each hell there are 84,000 subsidiary hells as its retinue.

In this place, the suffering of being boiled and roasted, the pain of peeling off skin and flesh, scraping bones and marrow, pulling out intestines and lungs, the immeasurable sufferings cannot be heard or spoken of.
Homage to the Buddha!
Those who are in this hell now may have been our parents or relatives from beginningless time. After we die, we may also fall into such a hell.

Today, we wash our hearts and sincerely kowtow and bow our heads to the Buddhas in the ten directions and the great earth bodhisattvas, seeking their compassion and repentance, to make all these karmic hindrances ultimately disappear.

May the disciples, by repenting of the merits produced by the retributions of hells and so forth, wish to be born in life after life, and the Buddhas' compassion to save sentient beings from suffering, will then break the AvÄ«ci iron city and all become pure lands with no name of evil paths.

The various painful conditions of the remaining hells will be transformed into conditions of happiness. The sword trees will become jeweled beds. The boiling cauldrons and burning coals will transform into lotus flowers. The ox-headed guards will abandon their violence and all give rise to compassion, without any evil thoughts.

The beings in hell, having escaped the fruits of suffering and no longer creating causes, equally experienced peace and joy like the third dhyÄna, and at the same time all gave rise to the unsurpassed aspiration for enlightenment.
The Sutra of the Questions and Answers of the MahÄyÄna Lotus Treasure-Reaching Åšramaá¹‡a, Scroll 1. Treasure-Reaching entered the Drinking Fire and Iron Hell.
Why is it called the Drinking Fire and Iron Hell?

The hell is three hundred yojanas long and wide, surrounded by iron walls, with smoke and fire rising together. On the ground there are cauldrons filled with boiling iron grains, mixed with boiling water, and on the sides there are horse-headed rÄká¹£asas holding iron ladles stirring the iron grains.
In the east gate there were eight thousand Å›ramaá¹‡as, crying and weeping, their body hairs burning with fire and smoke rising together, and the sinful monks collapsed at every step.

The horse-headed rÄká¹£asa held a three-pronged iron trident, thrusting it into their chests and coming out through their backs. The tines of the trident were burning with fire, penetrating through left and right. The yaká¹£a jailers held iron hooks, hooking them through their ribs and coming out through their mouths.
At that time, the eyes and mouths of the sinners were wide open.

At that time, the jailer took an iron ladle in his hand and poured iron pellets into the mouths of the sinners. As the iron pellets entered their mouths, smoke came out from their six sense organs, and flames blazed forth. Their pores also caught fire.

For a day and a night, they experienced myriad sufferings. They died a thousand times and were reborn a thousand times, died ten thousand times and were reborn ten thousand times. If they were able to be reborn as humans, their bodies would be incomplete, deaf, blind, mute, and they would not hear the Buddha's name. They would also not see a thousand Buddhas appear in the world.
Bodhisattva Baodai asked Horse-headed Raká¹£a:
What karma did these monks create to receive such punishment?
The Horse-headed Raká¹£a replied:
These monks received the pure precepts of the Buddha but did not uphold them purely. They ate the offerings of the faithful but did not observe the precepts.
They ate the food of the Sangha at night and also cooked their own food and took it themselves, without a sense of shame.
For these reasons, they receive such punishment.
